Fig. 1 Schematic illustration of catalyst synthesis procedure for Ni/O-clay30A and Ni/O-clay30B. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 A) X-ray diffraction characterization of reduced Ni/O-clay30A, Ni/O-clay30B, Ni/Bentonite30A, calcined organoclay, and calcined bentonite. TEM images of B) reduced Ni/O-clay30A, C) reduced Ni/O-clay30B, and D) used Ni/O-clay30A (after 6th cycle). Average particle size of E) reduced Ni/O-clay30A, F) reduced Ni/O-clay30B, and G) used Ni/O-clay30A (after 6th cycle). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 A) N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm, B-C) Pore diameter distribution profiles, and D-E) NH3-TPD of reduced Ni/O-clay catalysts. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 A-B) FE-SEM images of Ni/O-clay30A. HR-TEM images of C) Ni/O-clay30A showing Ni (111) plane, and D) Ni/O-clay30A showing NiO (200) plane. E) SAED pattern of Ni/O-clay30A. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Elemental mapping of Ni/O-clay30A. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Ni2p spectra of Ni/O-clay30A, Ni/O-clay30B, used Ni/O-clay30A (after 6th cycle), and Ni/Bentonite30A. Si2p and O1s spectra of Ni/O-clay30A. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Thermogravimetric analysis of A) calcined Ni/O-clay30B, and B) dried Ni/O-clay30A. C) FTIR analysis of Ni/O-clay30B and Ni/O-clay30A. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Impact of Ni/O-clay30A loading on the distribution of products during the hydrogenation process of FUR to THFA at different temperatures. A) 100 mg, B) 200 mg, C) 300 mg. 1 g Furfural, 20 mL H2O, 4.0 MPa H2, 1 h. Others: 2,2’-Difurfuryl ether. Rathod a ⁎ Mannepalli Lakshmi Kantam a ⁎ a Department of Chemical Engineering, Institute of Chemical Technology, Mumbai 400019, India Department of Chemical Engineering, Institute of Chemical Technology Mumbai 400019 India Department of Chemical Engineering, Institute of Chemical Technology, Mumbai, 400019, India b Catalysis and Inorganic Chemistry Division, CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory, Dr. Homi Bhabha Road, Pune 411008, India Catalysis and Inorganic Chemistry Division, CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory Dr. Homi Bhabha Road Pune 411008 India Catalysis and Inorganic Chemistry Division, CSIR-National Chemical Laboratory, Dr. Homi Bhabha Road, Pune, 411008, India. c Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR), Ghaziabad 201002, India Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR) Ghaziabad 201002 India Academy of Scientific and Innovative Research (AcSIR), Ghaziabad, 201002, India ⁎ Corresponding authors. Nickel supported on organoclay prepared by the impregnation method provides excellent catalytic activity for the hydrogenation of furfural to tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol. The relative amount of metal and acidic sites influences the hydrogenation reaction. Additionally, by varying the temperature and the H2 pressure, we can regulate the interaction of furfural with the active sites. And this may decide the fate of the reaction whether it will undergo a two-step hydrogenation to form tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol or a rearrangement reaction to form cyclopentanone/cyclopentanol. Water was found to be the best solvent for the selective formation of tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol. Even though alcohols inhibited rearrangement reaction, the hydrogenation of furfural was more selective towards furfuryl alcohol. Ni/O-clay30A under the optimum conditions of 120°C, 4.0 MPa, and in 1 h offered complete conversion of furfural to tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol. Graphical Abstract Keywords Nickel Organoclay Hydrogenation Furfural Tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The progress in civilization has triggered the exploitation of fossil fuels. Along with the increasing cost of fossil fuels, it also generates serious environmental concerns which are required to be addressed. As a substitute for fossil fuels, biomass has gained a prime in making biofuels and value-added products [1–3]. Lignocellulose is one of the cheapest biomass due to its abundance and non-palatability as compared to other agricultural feedstocks. The three types of polymers found in lignocellulose are cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin, and they can be utilized to produce various platform chemicals [4–6]. As one of the important and versatile platform chemicals, furfural (FUR) happens to be one of the major constituents in the manufacturing of bio-based chemicals. World production of FUR was conservatively estimated to be about 600,000 tonnes per annum by the year 2020 [7]. FUR can be produced by acid-catalyzed dehydration of xylose, which is extracted from hemicellulose found in agricultural waste materials, like corn cobs, sugarcane bagasse, oat hulls, peanut shells, corn stalks, wheat straw, almond husks, cottonseed hull bran, and wood chips [8–10]. Several processes, such as hydrogenation, oxidation, cyanation, and amination, can convert FUR into subsequent downstream compounds [11,12]. Among these processes, the hydrogenation of FUR is significant as it can be selectively converted into many important chemicals like furfuryl alcohol (FOL), tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA), 2-methyl furan, cyclopentanone (CPO), cyclopentanol (CPOL), and 2-methyl tetrahydrofuran which offers a wide variety of applications in the field of pharmaceuticals, perfumery, dyes, solvents, resins, and adhesives [13–16]. THFA is one of the most important hydrogenated products, which is colorless, less toxic, and high-boiling liquid [17,18]. It is an environmentally benign solvent widely used in the pharmaceutical and agro-industry sectors[12,19,20]. It can also be used to produce dihydropyran[21], pyridine[22], and tetrahydrofuran. Recently, the straight-chain polyols derived from THFA, such as 1,5-pentanediol regarded to be an important monomer in the polyurethane industry [23–25]. Additionally, THFA is an important industrial intermediate in producing electronic cleaners, printing inks, drugs, and synthetic fibers [26]. THFA can be synthesized by a classical two-step hydrogenation method, which involves FOL as an intermediate [13]. The reaction is feasible in both the liquid and gas phases [17]. The above method can also offer side reactions to give CPO or CPOL via Piancatelli rearrangement due to slightly acidic conditions in an aqueous medium [6]. The synthesis of THFA requires the hydrogenation of both a furan ring and an aldehydic group of FUR. Due to their excellent CC reduction activity, noble metal catalysts such as Pd, Rh, Ru, and Pt have been employed in the direct hydrogenation of FUR to THFA [27]. Biradar et al. used very extreme conditions for the THFA synthesis in the presence of palladium supported on a Si-MFI molecular sieve (3% Pd/MFI), offering 95% THFA selectivity by recycling the crude of the first hydrogenation experiment [28]. Milder conditions were employed by Cao et al. using Ru−MoOx/CN prepared by pyrolysis of chitin and metal salts which exhibited FUR conversion and THFA selectivity of 92% and 99%, respectively [29]. Li et al. achieved complete FUR conversion to THFA when hydroxyapatite was used as a support in the synthesis of the Pd catalyst [30]. This excellent catalytic activity was achieved under reaction conditions of 40°C, 10 bar H2, and 3 h using isopropanol as a solvent. Wu et al. observed 99% FUR conversion and 93% THFA yield at 35 °C and under 2 MPa H2 in the presence of a PtNi alloy catalyst [26]. Matsagar et al. used a commercial Rh/C catalyst to give a THFA yield of 92% in an aqueous medium [31]. It took 12 h for both the catalysts ( Pt and Rh) to achieve good results even when the catalyst amount was above 40 wt%. To develop an economically viable reaction, it is necessary to replace the noble metal catalysts with non-noble metal catalysts like Ni, Co, and Cu. Nakagawa et al. achieved a 94% yield of THFA in the gas phase hydrogenation of FUR at 130°C on Ni/SiO2 in 90 min. The highest activity was reached with small Ni crystallites (<4 nm) [32]. The presence of secondary metal improves the particle size and dispersion of Ni. Sanchez et al. [6] and Parikh et al.[33] designed highly dispersed NiCu and NiCo bimetallic catalysts to give excellent selectivity of 95% and 93%, respectively, with complete FUR conversion. Another way to increase dispersion is to introduce Ni directly into the precursor-based support. Ni-Mg/Al mixed oxides prepared from double-layered hydroxides afforded complete conversion of FUR and 80% THFA selectivity, which was reported by Aldureid et al. [27]. Alumina and its modified versions are widely used as supports in the hydrogenation of FUR. Sang et al. used a simple impregnation method to achieve FUR conversion of 99.8% and THFA selectivity of 99.5% when 15%Ni/γ-Alumina was used at 353°K, 4.0 MPa initial H2 pressure, and a reaction time of 2 h [18]. Yang et al. [17] synthesized Ba-modified Ni/Al2O3 catalysts to obtain 99% THFA selectivity. Su et al. developed carbon-embedded Ni (Ni/C) catalysts having an average particle size of Ni less than 14 nm, which resulted in complete conversion of FUR to THFA at 120°C, 1.0 MPa H2 pressure, and 1 h [34]. A comparison table for the hydrogenation of FUR with different catalysts has been described in Table S1. Clay as support has been used in several reactions such as esterification, oxidation, hydrogenation, alkylation, condensations, addition, elimination, etc [35]. Their large abundance, outstanding stability, and low cost make the reaction process economically and environmentally feasible. Thus, the utilization of clay material offers a great advantage over the other supports [36,37]. The use of clay material in the synthesis of THFA provided excellent results. Sunyol et al. altered the acidic properties of mesoporous clay with MgO. This modified clay was used as support for the Ni catalyst providing a complete conversion of FUR to THFA in an aqueous medium at 140°C, 40 bar H2, and 4 h [38]. Bentonite is a clay mineral developed from volcanic ash majorly comprised of montmorillonite [39,40]. Its excellent adsorption and cation exchangeable properties make it an excellent candidate in the field of catalysis. Its properties are enhanced further by certain modifications, such as pillaring with exchangeable cations. Another modification with quaternary salts/surfactants improves the pore size and surface area of bentonite [41]. Herein, we report a highly dispersed nickel organoclay (organo clay prepared by treating bentonite with cetyltrimethylammonium bromide) catalyst for the hydrogenation of FUR to THFA in the presence of water as a solvent. The direct reduction of nickel catalyst provides small particle size, which in return gives complete conversion of FUR to THFA ( Fig. 1). Thus, the Ni/O-clay catalyst offers excellent catalytic activity for the hydrogenation of FUR to THFA under mild conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Organoclay [42] and bentonite were obtained from Godavari Biorefineries Ltd. Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O (98%) was acquired from SDFCL. Furfural (98%) was obtained from Molychem. Furfuryl alcohol (>98%) was sourced from Spectrochem Pvt. Ltd. Tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (>98%), cyclopentanone (>99%), and cyclopentanol (>99%) were obtained from TCI Pvt. Ltd. Ethanol (99.9%) was procured from Changshu Hongsheng Fine Chemicals Co. Ltd. Methanol (99.8%) and isopropyl alcohol (99.5%) were procured from High Purity Laboratory Chemicals Pvt Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Organoclay was prepared by treating bentonite with cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB, 99% purity) [42]. The catalysts used in the study were prepared through the standard impregnation method. Initially, 15 g of organoclay was subjected to a drying process (100°C) in an oven for one hour to eliminate any moisture content. Subsequently, 10 g of the dried organoclay was gradually dispersed into a 200 mL deionized water solution containing 14.86 g of nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O). The dispersion was vigorously stirred for one hour. The resulting suspension was then evaporated into a thick slurry. The slurry is dried overnight in a hot air oven at 80°C and directly reduced at a temperature of 500°C, 600°C, and 700°C for two hours in a flow of hydrogen gas (H2) to afford Ni/O-clay30D, Ni/O-clay30A, and Ni/O-clay30C. Similarly, catalysts with 10% and 20% metal loading, denoted as Ni/O-clay10A and Ni/O-clay20A, respectively, were prepared. Another variant, Ni/O-clay30B, was prepared by calcining (550°C for 4 h in the air) the dried catalyst followed by the impregnation process. Then the catalyst was reduced at 600°C for two hours under a flow of hydrogen gas (H2). 2.3 Experimental procedure A 100 mL autoclave made of Hastelloy (manufactured by Amar Equipment's Pvt. Ltd) was employed for the hydrogenation process of FUR to THFA. Before the hydrogenation reaction, the FUR was subjected to distillation. A total of 1.0 g of FUR (corresponding to 10.41 mmol) dissolved in deionized water, along with a specific amount of catalyst, was introduced into the autoclave. To eliminate any residual air, the autoclave was initially purged with nitrogen. Subsequently, the autoclave was pressurized with hydrogen (H2). Throughout the reaction, the mixture was stirred at a constant speed of 1000 rpm. The point at which the inner temperature of the autoclave reached the desired temperature was considered the starting point of the reaction (to). The hydrogenation reaction lasted for 1 hour. 2.4 Characterization methods The atomic and molecular arrangement of crystals present in the catalysts and support was analyzed by XRD using a Rigaku Smart Lab SE instrument, The scan covered a 2θ range of 5°–80°. The Debye-Scherrer method was employed to determine the crystallite size of Ni in Ni/O-clay catalysts. The morphological properties of the catalyst were investigated using a Carl Zeiss Supra 55 model, FE-SEM, and JEOL, HR-TEM. The elemental composition of the catalysts was analyzed using energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) with the Carl Zeiss Supra 55 instrument. Elemental mapping was also performed using the Carl Zeiss Supra 55 instrument. The acid strength of the catalyst was assessed via NH3 temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) using the Micromeritics AutoChem HP 2950 V3.02 A instrument, which was equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) and a mass spectrometer (MS) to monitor the desorbed NH3. The catalyst sample underwent an initial degassing process wherein it was subjected to 600°C temperature for 30 minutes, utilizing helium (He) gas as the purging medium. The acid concentration was also determined through FT-IR spectroscopy employing pyridine as a molecular probe. To prepare the samples, they were subjected to degassing at 150°C for 2 hours, followed by cooling under vacuum and saturation with liquid pyridine for 1 hour. Physisorbed pyridine was removed by heating the samples to 110°C. The spectra of the samples were analyzed by using the KBr pellets on a Bruker FTIR 80 V instrument within the wavenumber range of 1700–1300 cm−1. The Micrometrics ASAP 2020 apparatus was utilized to acquire nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms. Before the analysis, all samples were subjected to a 6-hour degassing process at 300°C. The surface area was analyzed by the multipoint BET method, while the BJH method was used to determine pore size and pore volume. The dispersion of metallic nickel (Ni) atoms was quantified through pulsed titration of nitrous oxide (N2O) utilizing the BELCAT-2 TPX instrument (Japan). The catalyst was initially reduced at 600°C for 2 h. 200 mg of this reduced catalyst was loaded into a quartz tube. Helium gas served as the carrier gas, flowing at a rate of 10 mL min−1. Successive doses of a 10% N2O/He gas mixture were incrementally introduced into the helium stream through a calibrated injection valve, delivering 15 μL of N2O per pulse at a constant temperature of 60°C. The resulting product gases, nitrogen (N2), and the unreacted N2O, were subjected to analysis via thermal conductivity detection (TCD). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to study the chemical states of the catalyst using a Thermo K-Alpha Plus spectrometer equipped with a monochromated Al-Kα source (E=1486.6 eV). Throughout the data acquisition process, the charge neutralization gun was activated. The binding energy of the samples was crosschecked and referenced to adventitious C1s at 284.6 eV. Thermogravimetric analysis was conducted employing the NETZSCH STA 2500 instrument to investigate the thermal and decomposition properties of the dried catalyst. The investigations were carried out in a controlled environment with pure nitrogen gas flow, spanning a temperature range from 27°C to 800°C, and a heating rate of 4 °C/min. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was performed using Bruker FTIR 80 V instrument. To extract the reaction mass from water, ethyl acetate was employed, and the organic layer was analyzed by GC (TG-5 MS column). The products were identified using the Thermo Scientific HR-MS ISQ-LT 1300 instrument. To confirm the absence of any traces of products in the aqueous phase, HPLC analysis was carried out by a Thermofisher UHPLC instrument equipped with an ion-exchanged resin column (Agilent Hi-plex) and RI detector (Fig. S1). The conversion of FUR and the selectivity of THFA were calculated and defined using the following formula: % C o n v e r s i o n = I n t i a l m o l e s o f r e a c t a n t − m o l e s o f r e a c t a n t a t t i m e t I n i t i a l m o l e s o f r e a c t a n t × 100 % S e l e c t i v i t y = M o l e s o f d e s i r e d p r o d u c t M o l e s o f r e a c t a n t c o n s u m e d × 100 3 Results and discussions The XRD of reduced Ni/O-clay30A, Ni/O-clay30B, Ni/Bentonite30A, organoclay, and bentonite have been compared in Fig. 2. In organoclay and bentonite, the presence of montmorillonite planes is verified by diffraction peaks at 2θ= 19.9° and 35.6° which corresponded to the (101) and (107) planes of montmorillonite (JCPDS card NO. 29–1499). The 2θ= 20.9° and 26.8°are the diffraction peaks corresponding to the (101) and (107) planes of SiO2 (JCPDS card NO. 46–1045) [43]. The intercalation of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) in bentonite does not alter the morphology of the clay since organoclay shows similar diffraction as bentonite. However, the intensity for the above diffractions weakens with the introduction of CTAB and diminishes further with nickel. No distinct changes in the peak intensity of the reduced Ni/O-clay30A, Ni/Bentonite30A, and Ni/O-clay30B were visible at 2θ= 44.5°, 51.9°, and 76.5°, which correspond to (111), (200), (220) planes of metallic Ni (JCPDS card NO. 04–0850) [44]. The increase in the nickel loading can be confirmed by Fig. 2A (SI) , which exhibits the increase in the peak intensity as we move from Ni/O-clay10A to Ni/O-clay30A. A direct reduction of Ni/O-clay30A and Ni/Bentonite30A revealed a weak broad peak at 2θ= 43.6° corresponding to the (200) plane of NiO (JCPD card NO. 47–1049), which is verified by HR-TEM (Fig. 4 D) and SAED (Fig. 4 E) exhibiting lattice fringes of NiO (200) plane [44,45]. NiO phase was not detected in the reduced Ni/O-clay30B. The crystallite size varies when the catalyst is introduced to different thermal methods, which influence the catalytic activity of Ni/O-clay. The CTAB assists in the lowering of particle size during the direct reduction of Ni/O-clay by 15.5 nm (Ni/O-clay30B) to 10.9 ( Ni/O-clay30A). This allows good dispersion of Ni on the support, providing excellent hydrogenation activity. Table 1 summarizes the specific surface area, average pore diameter, and pore volume of the Ni/O-clays, bentonite, and organoclay. The CTAB, which is a good intercalator agent, has been employed to enhance the surface area of the clay material. After CTAB treatment, the specific surface area of bentonite was 104 m2 g−1. After loading with nickel, the surface area decreased in reduced Ni/O-clay10A, which further decreased in Ni/O-clay20A. The pore diameter and pore volume remain the same throughout the series of catalysts except for Ni/O-clay30A, where the pore diameter is reduced to half, which may result in increased surface as compared to the other Ni/O-clay catalysts. This may have arisen from the formation of new pores due to the blockage of old pores resulting from high nickel content [46,47]. The textural properties can explain the activity of Ni/O-clay in the hydrogenation of FUR to THFA with the help of N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm and pore size distribution ( Fig. 3 ). Type IV isotherm was observed in N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm, which according to IUPAC nomenclature indicates mesoporous material [44,48,49]. The N2 adsorption capacity of Ni/O-clay30A is higher as compared to Ni/O-clay30B with an increase in relative pressure which may suggest high multilayer formation in Ni/O-clay30A as compared to Ni/O-clay30B indicating better adsorption ability. The H3-type hysteresis loop is observed in the medium and high-pressure region (P/P0 ˃ 0.4), indicating the presence of platelet particles forming mesopores slit-shaped which are confirmed from FE-SEM. Fig. 3 B, Fig. 3 C, and Fig. 3 (SI) show the pore diameter distribution profile of different catalysts and support. The average pore size is found to be in between the range of 2–50 nm, confirming the catalysts and supports are mesoporous materials. The average pore diameter of organoclay (3.9 nm) is greater than bentonite (3.8 nm), indicating the intercalation of CTAB improving the pore size of bentonite Fig. 3 (SI). The N2O pulse titration analysis of Ni/O-clay catalysts is detailed in Table 1. Among Ni/O-clay30A, Ni/O-clay20A, and Ni/O-clay10A, heightened metal loading leads to enhanced metal dispersion. This improvement is attributed to the direct reduction of the catalysts, potentially amplifying the metal-support interaction and thereby increasing the metal surface area. Conversely, the calcination of Ni/O-clay30B in air impedes the formation of small nanoparticles, resulting in a lower dispersion of metal on the support. Bentonites are acidic clays, which on modification to organoclay enhance its acidic properties. The broad asymmetric peaks observed in NH3-TPD (Figs. 3 D and 3 E) signify multiple acidic sites with three desorption regions, weak(100−200), medium (300−400), and strong acidic sites (500−700). The quantity of ammonia desorbed from the samples gives rise to the intensity of specific peaks [17]. The overall acid concentration decreased with Ni loading due to the partial concealing of surface acid sites (Table 1) [50]. Acidity lowers by more than 50% from 98 µmole/g to 46 µmole/g with successive Ni loading. The higher total acidity of Ni/O-clay30A compared to Ni/O-clay30B and Ni/Bentonite30A explains its superior performance in the hydrogenation of FUR to THFA. The peak intensity of the medium acidic site region increases with metal loading, especially in the region of 300 °C, with Ni/O-clay30A exhibiting the highest desorption peak [51]. Thus, with successive metal loading, the metallic Ni gets transferred toward the strong acid site region. The strong acid site regions exhibit medium desorption peaks whose intensity decreases with metal loading as we go from Ni/O-clay10A to Ni/O-clay30A. This indicates the strong acid sites get masked with successive metal loading [51]. Thus, the complete hydrogenation of FUR to THFA is felicitated by medium acidic sites in Ni/O-clay30A. Table 1 shows the total acidic sites in different nickel clay catalysts [52]. The Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) analysis of pyridine adsorption provides insights into the presence of both Bronsted and Lewis acid sites, as depicted in Fig. 4A (SI). Specifically, peaks observed at 1637 cm-1 and 1535 cm-1 indicate the formation of pyridinium ions (PyH+), representing Bronsted acid sites. Pyridine molecules bound to Lewis acid sites exhibit characteristic peaks at 1622 cm-1 and 1460 cm-1 [52–55]. With increasing nickel loading, the absorbance related to Lewis acid sites decreases, reaching its lowest in Ni/O-clay30A and Ni/O-clay30B samples. In contrast, Bronsted acid sites remain unaltered, implying the masking of Lewis acid sites by nickel particles. The reduction in overall acidity observed in NH3-TPD results from the saturation of nickel adsorption on Lewis acid sites. Consequently, the acidity in Ni/O-clay30B is primarily governed by Bronsted acid sites. The significant role of Lewis acid sites in augmenting the adsorption of furfural (FUR) on to the support is noteworthy [13]. These Lewis acid sites actively promote the adsorption process of FUR on to the support material. As demonstrated in Fig. 4B (SI), Ni/O-clay30A exhibits a higher concentration of Lewis acid sites in comparison to Ni/O-clay30B, indicating a more substantial adsorption capacity for FUR on to the support. Figs. 4 A and 4 B show the FE-SEM analysis of Ni/O-clay30A. No change was observed in modified bentonite which showed similar characteristic features to montmorillonite (Fig. 5A, SI and Fig. 5B, SI). The surface of organoclay exhibits a mesoporous structure containing many ordered layers of splintered sheets. After the impregnation process, the platelets are covered with nickel nitrate precursor (Fig. 5C, SI and Fig. 5D, SI), which after reduction, converts to metallic Ni, which is seen widely dispersed in reduced Ni/O-clay30A (Figs. 4 A and 4B). This shows that nickel was impregnated on organoclay successfully, which was also confirmed by elemental mapping ( Fig. 5 ). No morphological changes were found in the used Ni/O-clay30A after 6 cycles which exhibits the stability of the catalyst (Fig. 5E, SI and Fig. 5F, SI). The energy-dispersive X-ray analysis shows the amount of Ni present in every catalyst (Table 1). The preparation of Ni/O-clay catalyst with 10, 20, and 30 wt% nickel loading is also verified by XRD analysis, exhibiting an increase in the intensity of diffraction peaks with every successive increase in Ni loading. The morphologies of Ni/O-clay catalysts are studied by TEM and HR-TEM (Fig. 2 and Fig. 4). Fig. 2 B shows Ni nanoparticles having an average particle size of 9 nm. This may result due to the direct reduction of dried catalyst assisted by the surfactant CTAB. Ni/O-clay30B (Fig. 2 C), which is calcined and reduced, tends to produce Ni particles of varied sizes with an average particle size of 14 nm. This huge difference in particle size by varying thermal methods decides the catalytic activity of Ni/O-clay. Hence, the nanosized particles of Ni/O-clay30A perform excellently in the hydrogenation of FUR. The HR-TEM of reduced Ni/O-clay30A (Figs. 4 C and 4 D), Ni/O-clay30B (Fig. 6A, SI and Fig. 6B, SI), and used Ni/O-clay30A (Fig. 6D, SI and Fig. 6E, SI) exhibits precise lattice fringes with lattice spacings of 0.204 nm corresponding to Ni (111) in accordance with XRD and SAED patterns. The direct reduction did not felicitate complete reduction of the catalyst, which can be observed in HR-TEM images of the reduced Ni/O-clay30A with the presence of NiO (200) planes. The presence of metallic Ni and NiO phases is also confirmed by SAED (Fig. 4E), where diffraction rings of Ni (111), Ni (200), Ni (220), NiO (200), and NiO (111) can be observed in SAED pattern in Ni/O-clay30A. The NiO phase was still observed in HR-TEM and SAED of Ni/O-clay30A after the recycling (Fig. 6F, SI). The chemical state of the reduced catalyst was studied using XPS analysis ( Fig. 6). All the catalyst shows the presence of metallic Ni with spin-orbital doublet at 852.7 eV and 870.4 eV corresponding to Ni2p3/2 and Ni2p1/2 respectively with spin energy separation of 17.7 eV [14,53]. Due to the exposure to the ambient atmosphere, the surface of the reduced catalyst undergoes hydroxylation, forming Ni(OH)2 [54,55]. The Ni2p3/2 and Ni2p1/2 peaks for Ni(OH)2 are observed at 856.6 eV and 874.1 eV, respectively, along with two corresponding satellite peaks situated at 861.75 eV and 879.7 eV. The spin energy separation of the two principal peaks is 17.5 eV, which is attributed to the typical binding energies Ni(OH)2 phase [56]. The Ni/Ni(OH)2 ratio in Ni/O-clay30B (0.24) appears to be higher than that in Ni/O-clay30A (0.18), indicating a greater rate of hydroxylation in Ni/O-clay30A. This discrepancy can be linked to the nanoparticle size of Ni/O-clay30A (Table S2). There is a decrease in the peak intensity of metallic Ni in used Ni/O-clay30A [57]. Similarly, a lower amount of surface metallic Ni explains the moderate activity of Ni/Bentonite30A Table 2 (SI) . The unaffected chemical state of the used Ni/O-clay30A catalyst suggests high catalyst stability. The introduction of nickel gave rise to a complex Ni3p peak at 66.2 eV in Al2p spectra, and therefore deconvolution was avoided (Fig. 7, SI) [58,59]. The binding energy of 74.8 eV corresponds to Al2O3 [59]. The presence of Fe2+ can be observed with spin-orbital doublet at 708.6 eV and 722 eV corresponding to Fe2p3/2 and Fe2p1/2, along with their satellite peaks having spin energy separation of 13.4 eV. The binding energies at 711.6 eV and 724.8 eV with their satellite peaks correspond to Fe2p3/2 and Fe2p1/2 with spin energy separation of 13.2, suggesting the Fe3+ phase. Thus, both the Fe2+ and Fe3+ phases are present in the reduced catalyst (Fig. 8, SI) [60–64]. The O1s comprises three sub-peaks in O1s spectra at 530.2, 531.6, and 532.8, corresponding to three types of oxygen from Al2O3, Ni(OH)2, and SiO2 respectively (Fig. 6) [53,65]. In Si2p spectrum binding energies at (103.7 eV), 102.8 eV, and (101.6 eV) correspond to SiO2, aluminosilicate, and Si(OH)4 phases (Fig. 6) [63–68]. The presence of aluminosilicate confirms the presence of montmorillonite. To examine the impact of CTAB on nickel particle size, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted to explore the thermal stability and decomposition characteristics of calcined Ni/O-clay30B and dried Ni/O-clay30A, as illustrated in Figs. 7A and 7B. The Ni/O-caly30B after calcination at 550°C for 4 hours in the presence of air shows the absence of CTAB, as the process causes the decomposition of CTAB from the catalyst. TGA experiments were conducted within the temperature range of 30°C to 800°C. For Ni/O-caly30B, weight loss occurred between 100°C to 200°C and for Ni/O-clay30A between 150°C to 250°C, attributed to the removal of water molecules from both the external surface and the clay gallery [69]. This process was accompanied by an endothermic peak in the DTA analysis at around 200°C for both catalysts. Furthermore, weight loss between 250°C to 300°C, accompanied by an endothermic peak at 290°C in DTA, corresponded to the decomposition of Ni(NO3)2·6 H2O into NiO [70]. The final weight loss observed between 400°C to 500°C in both catalysts was associated with the dihydroxylation of montmorillonite [71]. Additionally, the decomposition of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) in Ni/O-clay30A occurred between 250°C to 300°C, indicated by an exothermic peak at 290°C in DTA. This peak suggested a pre-decomposition interaction between nickel and CTAB [69]. This potentially contributes to the smaller particle size of nickel in Ni/O-clay30A Table 1. The absence of CTAB in the organoclay of Ni/O-clay30B resulted in the lack of visible exothermic peaks, thereby precluding the interaction between CTAB and Ni. The absence of CTAB in both reduced Ni/O-clay30B and Ni/O-clay30A catalysts was confirmed by the Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) analysis depicted in Fig. 7 C. The absence of strong absorptions at 2918 and 2850 cm−1 caused by the C−H stretching vibration of methyl and methylene groups of CTAB confirms Ni/O-clay30B and Ni/O-clay30A are CTAB free [71]. 4 Catalytic test The influence of thermal methods and support modification on nickel during the hydrogenation of FUR is explained in Table 2. The TGA (Fig. 7.) studies show that the direct reduction of Ni/O-clay30A tends to produce nanosized particles caused by interaction between CTAB and Ni facilitating excellent metal dispersion (Table 1) as compared to a Ni/O-clay30B, which is calcined and further reduced. The high metal dispersion provides a greater metal surface area which helps in increased hydrogen adsorption, enhancing the catalytic activity of Ni/O-clay30A with 100% FUR conversion and 100% THFA selectivity. Ni/O-clay30A exhibits more acidic sites as compared to Ni/O-clay30B which may also assist in THFA formation. The catalytic activity relies upon the amount of metal content and acidic sites to yield high THFA selectivity. The introduction of CTAB in bentonite not only enhances the surface area and the acidic properties of Ni/O-clay30A but also enhances the metal dispersion of Ni as compared to unmodified bentonite nickel catalysts. To investigate the influence of acid sites, hydrogenation of FUR to THFA was conducted by introducing 1 mmole of pyridine into the reaction mixture. As shown in Table 2, the results revealed a significant decrease in the catalytic activity of Ni/O-clay30A for THFA synthesis, with 100% FUR conversion, 28% THFA selectivity, and 72% FOL selectivity. This suggests that acid sites facilitate the adsorption of FUR onto the support's acidic sites [13]. The catalyst reduced at 500°C (Ni/O-clay30D) and 700°C (Ni/O-clay30C) provided THFA selectivity of 81% and 100% selectivity, with both exhibiting 100% FUR conversion. The diminished selectivity of tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol (THFA) observed in Ni/O-clay30D, attributable to its larger crystallite size in comparison to the catalysts reduced at 600°C and 700°C, highlights the significant influence of crystallite dimensions on catalytic performance (Fig. 2C, SI). In contrast, Ni/O-clay30A (600°C) and Ni/O-clay30C (700°C) exhibited similar crystallite sizes, resulting in comparable catalytic activities. Considering the reduced time and energy input demanded by Ni/O-clay30A, it was selected as the optimal catalyst for further optimization studies. The results of FUR to THFA at 50% FUR conversion using Ni/O-clay30A and Ni/O-clay30B are depicted in Table 2 , which confirms the rate of intermediate (FOL) is higher in Ni/O-clay30A than Ni/O-clay30B. The Ni/Bentonite30A exhibits 5% THFA selectivity, thus favoring more towards FOL (95% selectivity). The lower Ni content in Ni/O-clay20A and Ni/O-clay10A favors FOL over THFA with selectivity over 90%. This may be due to the lower surface area, which gives rise to low metal dispersion on the support (Table 1). The Ni/O-clay consists of two active sites, the active metal sites for the hydrogenation of the aldehyde group, which effortlessly converts FUR to FOL, and the acidic sites whose influence will decide whether FOL will undergo further hydrogenation or rearrangement reaction. These competing sites may affect the selectivity of THFA by producing secondary products such as CPO and CPOL or may undergo resinification ( Scheme 1). Therefore, the hydrogenation of FUR depends on the relative amount of metal and acidic sites along with the relative activity of these sites. Fig. 8 shows the effect of catalyst loading at different temperature spans on the hydrogenation of FUR. While investigating the effect of catalyst amount on the reaction, no resinification products were produced throughout the temperature span. Below 150°C, the low catalyst amount (100 mg) favors FOL with selectivity above 60%. With the increase in temperature, the FOL selectivity lowers as it converts to CPO. At 180°C, the CPO exhibits a maximum selectivity of 73%. THFA selectivity remains below 20% between 100°C to 140°C. The FUR conversion gradually increases from 15% to 96%, corresponding to an increase in temperature from 100°C to 180°C. The lower catalyst amount thus favors CPO formation above 150°C due to the corresponding low Ni amount causing selective hydrogenation of CO in FUR and excluding CC in the furan ring promoting FOL formation [72,73]. Above 150°C, the Bronsted acid sites further assist in the dehydration of the hydroxyl group in the FOL and the subsequent ring rearrangement to the intermediate of 4-hydroxy-2-cyclopentenone with further dehydration and hydrogenation to yield CPO [52]. With the increase in the catalyst loading, the hydrogenation reaction tends to favor THFA. When the catalyst amount is increased to 200 mg, it gives 93% THFA selectivity with 99% FUR conversion at 150°C. Here too, the reaction becomes more selective toward CPO at high temperatures with 63% CPO selectivity. The FUR conversion remains above 97% throughout the temperature study. The further increase in catalyst amount gives a corresponding rise in metal and acidic sites with adsorption of both CO and furan ring in FUR to selectively form THFA at a very high rate. The high amount of active (metal and acidic) sites allows facile adsorption of both the functional groups (furan and CO), resulting in complete conversion of FUR to THFA at a very low temperature of 120°C and 130°C. The THFA selectivity lowers above 130°C with the gradual formation of CPO which eventually reaches 84% THFA selectivity at 180°C. No CPOL formation was observed suggesting the need for high-pressure conditions above 4 MPa for the formation of CPOL. The influence of different solvents on the hydrogenation of FUR by varying the catalyst concentration was studied. Polar protic solvents were selected to study solvent effects. Fig. 9 (SI) shows poor selectivity towards THFA when alcohols are employed for the hydrogenation of FUR. The THFA selectivity remains low even with an increase in catalyst amount whereas FOL selectivity increases with increasing the catalyst amount. The low THFA selectivity is the result of the low polarity of the alcohols as compared to water. The FOL formed in alcohols promotes competing reactions like reductive etherification and acetalization further lowering the selectivity of THFA. Water has low hydrogen-bond acceptance ability (β), which tends to activate CO functional group in FUR to felicitate THFA formation [31]. Thus, water shows excellent activity for THFA with a corresponding increase in catalyst amount. Instead of post-reaction THFA extraction via ethyl acetate, we initiated the reaction with a coexisting mixture of aqueous hydrogenation of FUR and ethyl acetate (in a 1:1 ratio) (Table 2). This approach resulted in diminished THFA selectivity, yielding only 9%. Given that high-polarity solvents are imperative for THFA formation, the introduction of ethyl acetate reduced the overall polarity of the solvent system, consequently diminishing THFA yield. Hydrogen pressure has a high impact on the selective hydrogenation of FUR to THFA. The reactions were carried out in the water by keeping the catalyst amount constant at 30 wt%. The reduction of the aldehydic group in FUR to FOL (intermediate) is less challenging as compared to the CC of the furan ring. From Fig. 9 it is evident that low H2 pressure (2 MPa) inhibits the hydrogenation of the furan ring and allows selective hydrogenation of the C-O group of FOL to felicitate rearrangement reaction to give CPO at high temperature [74]. It is evident from the results that the selectivity for THFA remains low throughout the temperature span. This confirms the FOL conversion to CPO with the highest CPO selectivity of 99% along with 96% FUR conversion at 180°C. The hydrogenation of FUR above 2.0 MPa tends to lead the reaction toward THFA with high FUR conversion above 96% throughout the temperature span. At 160°C and 3.0 MPa H2 pressure, the hydrogenation of FUR produces THFA with 95% selectivity with 100% FUR conversion. However, above 160°C, the reaction favors C-O hydrogenation leading to rearrangement, forming CPO with the highest selectivity of 93% at 180°C and 3.0 MPa H2 pressure. The absence of CPOL below 4.0 MPa shows the need for high H2 pressure to reduce CPO. At 4.0 MPa, the conditions are ideal for the complete hydrogenation of FUR to THFA. At 4.0 MPa H2 pressure and 120°C, the relative metal and acidic sites allow facile hydrogenation of FUR with complete conversion of FUR to THFA. With an increase in temperature, the THFA selectivity lowers to 84% at 180°C. At 5.0 MPa, the maximum THFA selectivity (76%) was obtained at 140°C with 100% FUR conversion. The THFA selectivity lowers with a further increase in temperature due to corresponding CPOL formation. This results from the combined effect of high temperature and H2 pressure leading to the rapid conversion of CPO to CPOL on the surface of the catalyst [75]. Fig. 10 illustrates the distribution of products under various pressures at different reaction times. Temperature was kept constant at 120°C throughout the parameter study. Despite an extended duration, THFA selectivity remains consistently low at 2.0 MPa and 3.0 MPa H2 pressure. Notably, at 4.0 MPa, the THFA selectivity remains unchanged (100%), indicating that at lower temperatures, THFA does not undergo C-O hydrogenolysis to yield pentanediols. Beyond 4.0 MPa, the elevated H2 pressure tends to favor the production of cyclopentanone (CPO) and cyclopentanol (CPOL), leading to a decline in THFA selectivity with increasing reaction time. 4.1 Catalyst recyclability The recyclability studies were carried out with Ni/O-clay30A ( Fig. 11). The catalyst was filtered and washed with methanol after each cycle. Attempts were also made to recover the traces of catalyst from the autoclave by rinsing it with water to minimize the catalyst loss. Thus, the catalyst activity was tested for over 6 cycles. The catalyst exhibited good activity with FUR conversion above 90% for the first 4 cycles. The first three cycles exhibit stable activity with 100% FUR conversion and THFA selectivity above 90%. The FUR conversion and THFA selectivity started to decrease below 90% after the 4th cycle and in the 6th cycle conversion and selectivity of 68% and 69%, respectively were observed due to the loss of catalyst. To determine the heterogeneity of the catalyst, we have carried out two experiments. In the first experiment, the reaction was terminated after one hour. At this juncture, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture at the reaction temperature (120°C) and the reaction was continued with the filtrate for an additional 3 hours. The conversion was found to remain almost identical before and after the removal of the catalyst. In the second experiment, the Ni/O-clay30A catalyst was stirred at 120°C for three hours, and the filtrate was used for the hydrogenation of FUR to THFA at 120°C under 4.0 MPa H2 pressure for 1 hour. No product formation was observed. Hence, from these two experiments, it could be concluded that the reaction proceeds under heterogeneous conditions and that there are no leached nickel species in the solution. EDX (Table 1) analysis of the used catalyst does not show considerable loss of metal due to leaching, which is confirmed by XRD analysis wherein used Ni/O-clay30A exhibits diffraction peaks of nearly the same intensity as fresh Ni/O-clay30A. The increase in the metal particle size and the low surface area after the 6th cycle may be the reason for the low catalytic activity (Table 1 and Fig. 2). The increase in particle size of the Ni lowers the surface area of the metal and the adsorption of unreacted FUR lowers the surface area (Table 1) of the catalyst resulting in the decreased conversion and selectivity. The adsorption of FUR on the catalyst surface is confirmed by FTIR (Fig. 10, SI) which shows the presence of a CO peak in the range of 1600–1700 cm−1 and aromatic CC peak in the range of 1500–1600 cm−1 [76,77]. Another factor contributing to the decrease in catalytic activity after the 6th cycle is the reduction in the peak intensity of metallic Ni, accompanied by a corresponding increase in the peak intensity of Ni(OH)2 in XPS analysis. This shift is attributed to the high hydroxylation of Ni in the ambient atmosphere of the used Ni/O-clay30A, indicating a decline in catalytic activity[57]. No structural changes were observed in the used catalyst, which was confirmed by XRD. The used Ni/O-clay30A showed no changes in the diffraction peaks after the 6th cycle (Fig. 2B, SI). The slight decline in THFA selectivity is attributed to the formation of furfuryl alcohol (FOL) devoid of any by-product formation, FOL serves as an intermediate in the hydrogenation process of FUR to THFA. (Fig. 11). 5 Conclusion The selective hydrogenation of FUR to THFA is governed by several factors, which include relative metal and acidic sites, catalyst amount, hydrogen pressure, and temperature. The optimum conditions required were observed at 120°C and 4.0 MPa H2 pressure using Ni/O-clay30A as the catalyst. The CTAB assisted in high Ni dispersion over Ni/O-clay30A when the catalyst was reduced directly at 600°C under H2 flow. The absence of CTAB due to its degradation after calcination in Ni/O-clay30B and following reduction offered poor dispersion of metal. This decided the performance of the catalyst for the complete THFA formation. Adjusting the catalyst amount and hydrogen pressure may affect the adsorption of FUR on the active sites. The low catalyst amount offers less active sites, which are suitable for the hydrogenation of the aldehydic group, and excludes the furan ring which further undergoes rearrangement to CPO. Lower hydrogen pressure also plays a key role in the selective hydrogenation of the aldehydic group. The high temperature (>140°C) and pressure conditions (> 4.0 MPa) offer suitable conditions for the formation of CPOL. The THFA formation is highly favored in the presence of water as a solvent due to its high polarity as compared to other solvents. Hydrogenation of FUR in alcohols is less selective towards THFA and favors FOL more. Declaration of Competing Interest We declare that we have no conflict of interest. coredata.dc:description: Nickel supported on organoclay prepared by the impregnation method provides excellent catalytic activity for the hydrogenation of furfural to tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol. The relative amount of metal and acidic sites influences the hydrogenation reaction. Additionally, by varying the temperature and the H2 pressure, we can regulate the interaction of furfural with the active sites. And this may decide the fate of the reaction whether it will undergo a two-step hydrogenation to form tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol or a rearrangement reaction to form cyclopentanone/cyclopentanol. Water was found to be the best solvent for the selective formation of tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol. Even though alcohols inhibited rearrangement reaction, the hydrogenation of furfural was more selective towards furfuryl alcohol. Ni/O-clay30A under the optimum conditions of 120°C, 4.0 MPa, and in 1 h offered complete conversion of furfural to tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrogenation of furfural to tetrahydrofurfuryl alcohol over nickel-supported on organoclay catalyst
